origin_history: Part of mixed Herb Planter seeded on Nov 12, 2025.
Planted in black planter 23.5" × 7.85" × 6" left front
Shares planter with Cilantro, Parsley, Thyme, and Oregano.
whats_been_logged: The planting began with very dry, alkaline soil that was rehydrated and corrected with lime. Early germination was slow but steady as moisture stabilized and pH gradually shifted from alkaline to acidic, then naturally rebounded toward ideal range. Sprouts emerged healthy and upright, with first true-leaf tips now visible as the seedlings transition from germination into active early growth.
current_state: A healthy stand of Thai basil with upright stems and multiple sets of elongated true leaves actively expanding. Foliage is evenly green with no visible stress, wilting, or pest damage, and the soil is uniformly moist with good structure in the shared herb planter.

timeline.what_i_should_see: Tiny Paired Leaves Emerging at Nodes
Plant Looks Fuller and More Bushy
Dense Canopy Forming with Overlapping Leaves
Leaf Tips Long Enough for Light Pinching

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high near 80°F dropping to around 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: Thai basil plants appear healthy and increasingly full with elongated true leaves and upright stems. Foliage is evenly green with no signs of stress. Soil surface had dried and crusted due to wind exposure but was loosened and fluffed after probe insertion, restoring good structure and aeration while the root zone remains evenly moist.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today. Leave soil lightly fluffed to maintain surface aeration.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture over the next 1–2 days, especially with storms forecast. Resume watering only if moisture drops into the low-to-mid 40s. Continue allowing uninterrupted vegetative growth.

photos.caption: Overhead view of Thai basil showing fuller growth with evenly spaced elongated leaves and healthy coloration after wind exposure.
photos.tags: thai basil, vegetative growth, healthy leaves, fuller canopy

photos.caption: Angled view of Thai basil with upright stems and steady leaf expansion in a shared herb planter.
photos.tags: thai basil, early bushy growth, upright stems

journal.conditions: A 20 percent chance of showers and thunderstorms, partly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Thai basil plants appear fuller and more established with multiple elongated true leaves and upright stems. Leaf color remains even and healthy with no signs of stress following recent feeding. Soil surface is leveled and improved after adding potting mix to fill probe holes, and moisture remains high but is trending downward appropriately.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today. Allow the soil to continue drying naturally with breezy conditions.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture when readings fall below 60. Resume watering only when moisture reaches the 40–50 range. Continue watching for dense canopy formation and clearly extended tips suitable for first pinching.

photos.caption: Angled view of Thai basil showing fuller growth, upright stems, and healthy leaf expansion after soil top-off and recent feeding.
photos.tags: thai basil, vegetative growth, fuller canopy, healthy leaves

journal.conditions: Showers likely with a high of 81°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Thai basil plants remain upright and vigorous with multiple sets of elongated true leaves and steady stem thickening. Foliage is evenly green with no signs of stress or nutrient burn following yesterday’s feeding. Soil is visibly very wet, consistent with the saturated moisture reading and incoming rain conditions.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize. Allow the soil to dry down naturally to restore air exchange in the root zone.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture once readings fall below the 70 range. Resume normal watering only after moisture returns to the 40–60 range. Continue watching for fuller canopy formation and leaf overlap.

photos.caption: Overhead view of Thai basil showing fuller growth with multiple sets of elongated true leaves and healthy coloration after recent feeding.
photos.tags: thai basil, vegetative growth, leaf expansion, healthy foliage

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 79°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: Thai basil plants are upright and actively expanding with multiple elongated true leaves per stem. Foliage is evenly green with no signs of wilting, scorch, or pest damage, and stems are beginning to thicken as the plants continue early vegetative growth. Soil appears evenly moist with good structure and no surface crusting in the shared herb window box.
journal.actions: Do not water today; soil moisture is already ideal. Plan for a light feeding at the next morning watering to support continued vegetative expansion.
journal.next_steps: At the next morning watering, mix ½ teaspoon Purived 4-5-5 into 4–6 cups of water and apply evenly across the entire window box as the only watering. After feeding, recheck moisture in 24–48 hours and water again only if readings fall below the upper 30s. Continue monitoring leaf density and canopy thickening as the plants approach the first pinching window.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the diluted Purived solution could contact the basil leaves; confirmed that light foliar contact is safe at this strength when applied in the morning and does not require rinsing.
follow_up: [7:30 AM] Fertilized the entire herb box with 4 cups of diluted Purived 4-5-5 solution.

photos.caption: Overhead view of Thai basil showing upright stems and multiple sets of elongated true leaves entering early vegetative growth.
photos.tags: thai basil, early vegetative, true leaves, healthy growth

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 77°F dropping to 52°F overnight.
journal.observations: Thai basil seedlings show vigorous early vegetative growth with widening true leaves and upright posture across the entire patch. Leaf color is bright and even, and the soil appears uniformly moist following recent rain without showing signs of saturation. New leaf pairs are emerging, and stems remain firm with no evidence of cutworm activity after yesterday’s DeadBug application. The cilantro behind the basil also looks strong, signaling balanced moisture in the shared planter.
journal.actions: Do not water today; moisture is ideal and temperatures will remain moderate. Hold off on fertilizer until the basil produces slightly more foliage density. Leave the soil surface undisturbed as structure is currently excellent.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture late tomorrow morning and water only if values fall below the upper 30s. Continue watching for overlapping leaf layers and stem thickening as cues to begin very light Purived 4-5-5 feeding. Monitor soil temperature through the cool night to ensure continued morning recovery.

photos.caption: Thai basil seedlings showing widening true leaves and strong early vegetative growth with evenly moist soil.
photos.tags: thai basil, seedlings, true leaves, vegetative growth

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Thai basil seedlings appear vigorous and well-hydrated with upright posture and bright, even foliage. True leaves are widening and overlapping more densely, indicating active vegetative growth. The soil surface shows improved structure and uniformity after filling the probe hole and incorporating fresh Miracle-Gro Moisture Control Potting Mix. No signs of wilt, discoloration, or stress are visible, and the cilantro row behind remains equally healthy.
journal.actions: Do not water today; moisture is ideal and incoming rain may increase levels naturally. Hold off on fertilizer until foliage mass thickens further. Maintain current sun exposure and avoid additional soil disturbance.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture after tonight’s possible showers to ensure the basil does not sit above roughly 80 mS/cm for long. Begin watching for foliage layering as a signal to start very light Purived 4-5-5 feeding. Continue monitoring morning temperature dips and confirm steady afternoon recovery.
follow_up: [8:06 AM] Filled in the probe hole, fluffed the soil surface, and added Miracle-Gro Moisture Control Potting Mix to improve structure and even out moisture.

[4:38 PM] Sprayed Captain Jack’s DeadBug lightly across the entire window box at soil level to eliminate or expose any cutworms that may have dropped into the soil and to prevent potential nighttime stem damage to cilantro and the other herbs.

photos.caption: Thai basil seedlings with widening true leaves and improved soil structure after refreshing the surface.
photos.tags: thai basil, seedlings, true leaves, soil adjustment

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Thai basil seedlings appear vigorous and upright with expanding true leaves forming a dense, healthy patch. Leaf color is bright and even, and the soil surface shows uniform moisture despite earlier dry probe pockets. No signs of wilt, discoloration, or heat stress are present, and the shared planter remains balanced with the cilantro row also showing strong growth.
journal.actions: Do not water today; moisture is ideal and incoming rain will maintain hydration. Hold fertilizer until the seedlings develop more mature foliage and moisture begins cycling lower. Leave the soil surface undisturbed.
journal.next_steps: Expect moisture to rise slightly with rain; wait to water again until readings fall near the 40–50 mS/cm range. Recheck pH later this week to confirm continued stability and plan for very light Purived 4-5-5 feeding once growth and moisture cycling are consistent.

photos.caption: Thai basil seedlings with increasingly broad true leaves forming a dense patch in front of the cilantro row.
photos.tags: thai basil, seedlings, true leaves, healthy growth

journal.conditions: Patchy fog early, then sunny with a high near 86°F and a low around 66°F overnight, with a slight chance of showers Sunday afternoon.
journal.observations: The Thai basil patch is now well established with sturdy stems and overlapping true leaves forming a solid band of foliage in front of the cilantro. Leaves are a healthy, even green with no scorch or wilt, and the soil beneath the canopy reads as comfortably moist rather than saturated.
journal.actions: Do not water today; moisture near 59 mS/cm is ideal for this stage, even with the warm, sunny forecast. Leave the planter to dry down further before the next irrigation and hold all fertilizer until at least the next check when moisture and pH can be confirmed.
journal.next_steps: Plan to probe again within the next one to two days or sooner if conditions turn windier or hotter than expected. When moisture is cycling between roughly 30–60 mS/cm and pH continues to hover near the high 5s to 6–7 range, begin very light, infrequent feeding with Purived 4-5-5 while continuing to avoid overwatering.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the basil needed watering today given the warm, sunny forecast; confirmed that with moisture around 59 mS/cm and vigorous growth, no irrigation is needed and the planter should be allowed to dry further before the next watering.

photos.caption: Close-up of the Thai basil row showing many elongated true leaves overlapping and partially shading the soil, with a dense wall of cilantro foliage behind.
photos.tags: thai basil, true leaves, dense growth, cilantro background

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight, with wind gusts up to 19 mph.
journal.observations: The Thai basil now forms two full, bright-green cushions of foliage with leaves overlapping and beginning to shade the soil surface. Moisture has returned to an ideal mid-range after the prior saturation, salts are moderate, and pH has improved into a more workable mildly acidic band.
journal.actions: Do not water today; with moisture around 53 mS/cm and a warm, breezy forecast the plants are in a comfortable zone. Hold off on fertilizer for a little longer while the basil continues building foliage and the pH pattern stabilizes.
journal.next_steps: Recheck readings in the next one to two days, especially if wind gusts stay strong and dry the soil more quickly. If growth continues at this pace and conditions remain stable, plan the first very light Purived 4-5-5 feeding within the coming week.

photos.caption: Sunlit overhead view of Thai basil forming dense clumps of foliage that nearly cover the soil surface, with neighboring herbs visible nearby.
photos.tags: thai basil, dense foliage, overhead, early vegetative

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy through the afternoon with temperatures in the mid-70s°F and a low around 69°F overnight, with possible showers near 6 PM.
journal.observations: By early evening the Thai basil patch is lush and leafy with no wilting, but the soil is very wet following recent water and weather, and light at the sensor is low as the day winds down. Probe readings show high moisture, elevated salts, and a strongly acidic pH, suggesting the roots are sitting in a very saturated mix.
journal.actions: Do not apply any additional water or fertilizer; allow the planter to drain and the surface to dry naturally. Keep foliage as dry as possible and avoid disturbing the roots while the soil is this wet.
journal.next_steps: Take the next reading earlier in the day once the top of the soil has begun to dry and moisture has dropped closer to the 40–60 mS/cm range. Continue monitoring the acidic pH behavior and postpone any feeding until both moisture and pH are more stable.

photos.caption: Close-up of the Thai basil section in the late afternoon showing a dense patch of seedlings with broadening leaves over very dark, wet soil.
photos.tags: thai basil, dense seedlings, wet soil, evening

journal.conditions: Conditions not recorded in conversation.
journal.observations: The Thai basil has shifted from a fine seedling carpet into small, distinct plants with longer first true leaves spreading over the soil surface. Moisture is sitting in a healthy mid-range and pH has rebounded close to neutral, aligning well with the strong, even color in the foliage.
journal.actions: Do not water at this time; readings show a comfortable balance of moisture and salts with no visible stress in the basil. Continue to avoid fertilizer until the plants carry several sets of true leaves and this neutral pH pattern holds steady.
journal.next_steps: Plan another probe check within 1–2 days to confirm that moisture trends remain stable. If growth continues at this pace and readings stay healthy, begin considering a very gentle introduction of Purived 4-5-5 later in the coming week.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the planter showing Thai basil seedlings now forming distinct small plants with elongated leaves in front of the thicker cilantro stand.
photos.tags: thai basil, seedlings, true leaves, overhead

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 72°F dropping to 57°F overnight, with clearer conditions expected toward evening.
journal.observations: Thai basil seedlings share the front zone with cilantro nearby, and both appear upright with good color in the cooler morning conditions. The single reading taken between the two patches shows moderately dry soil but not extreme dryness, and there is no visible sagging or curling of basil foliage.
journal.actions: Hold off on watering for now; at 25 mS/cm the root zone is on the drier side but still comfortable, especially with the cooler daytime high. Let the basil enjoy this slightly drier stretch rather than topping off moisture immediately.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture within a day or two, ideally on a warmer morning. Plan to water the basil section when readings slip closer to 15–20 mS/cm or when the leaves start to lose their perky, upright posture.

photos.caption: Top-down view of the herb box showing Thai basil seedlings at the front and a dense patch of cilantro seedlings behind, with lightly dried soil at the surface.
photos.tags: thai basil, cilantro, seedlings, shared reading, overhead

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 81°F dropping to 65°F overnight, with rainy conditions expected around 6 PM.
journal.observations: The Thai basil seedlings are fuller and taller, forming a clear band at the front of the box with no visible wilt or yellowing. Moisture sits in a comfortable middle range after recent adjustments to fill probe pockets, while pH remains on the acidic side but is not yet reflected in any visible stress.
journal.actions: Skip watering today; the moisture level is already adequate and the incoming evening rain will add more water. Continue gently leveling and filling any probe-created voids rather than punching new deep holes close to the seedlings.
journal.next_steps: Check moisture again after the rain has passed to be sure the planter does not stay above roughly 80 mS/cm for long stretches. If repeated mid-range moisture readings still come with pH readings under about 5.0, plan for a very modest lime adjustment once the seedlings are slightly larger.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the Thai basil section after soil has been topped up, showing thicker seedling clusters and dark, evenly textured potting mix.
photos.tags: thai basil, seedlings, overhead, soil leveling

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight, with thunderstorms expected around 4 PM.
journal.observations: The Thai basil seedlings have thickened into two main patches with upright leaves, and the soil surface looks sun-warmed rather than bone-dry. The Thai basil reading shows moisture at 0.00 mS/cm while the nearby cilantro reading moments later shows reasonable moisture, indicating a moisture-sensor contact failure rather than truly dry soil under the basil.
journal.actions: Treat the 0.00 moisture value as a probe error rather than an emergency dryness signal. Do not soak the planter; if the top inch feels very powder-dry before the storms arrive, add only a small splash of water spread gently across the basil zone and let the incoming rain handle the rest.
journal.next_steps: Take a follow-up probe reading the day after the storms once the surface has drained to confirm that moisture has settled back into roughly the 30–60 mS/cm band and that pH is drifting back toward the mid-6s. Continue to hold off on fertilizer until roots are better established and readings are more consistent.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the shared planter showing Thai basil seedlings in the front section and cilantro seedlings behind them, with sun-warmed soil between the two patches.
photos.tags: thai basil, cilantro, seedlings, shared planter, overhead

journal.conditions: Sunny all day with a high of 84°F dropping to 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: The Thai basil seedlings are noticeably denser with small clusters beginning to form, and foliage remains upright despite very wet soil from the 2:33 PM watering. The probe shows saturated moisture and a strongly acidic pH, but leaves appear turgid and unstressed at this point.
journal.actions: Do not water again today; allow the planter to drain and the surface to dry naturally. Avoid applying any fertilizer while moisture and salts are elevated, and leave the root zone undisturbed so the seedlings can continue to root into the mix.
journal.next_steps: Take a late-morning reading tomorrow or the following day to confirm that moisture has dropped back toward the 40–60 mS/cm range. If pH continues to sit below about 5.0 after a couple of dry-down cycles, plan a very small top-dress of dolomite lime rather than any additional feeding.

photos.caption: Close-up of the Thai basil zone showing thicker clusters of seedlings emerging from very dark, freshly watered potting mix.
photos.tags: thai basil, seedlings, close-up, wet soil

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 81°F dropping to 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: The Thai basil seedlings form a thin but even carpet along the front of the herb box, with small paired seed leaves sitting upright and evenly spaced. Earlier dryness left the surface crumbly, but after the light rehydration the probe shows comfortably moist soil beneath and there are no signs of wilt or discoloration.
journal.actions: Do not add any more water this afternoon; current moisture around 55 mS/cm is comfortably high for seedlings. Avoid fertilizer while the young roots are still settling and allow the soil to dry back gradually before the next watering.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and pH in the next 24 hours, ideally with a late-morning reading. Plan to wait on any lime or fertilizer adjustments until seedlings have at least one full set of true leaves and pH behavior is clearer.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the Thai basil section showing a light carpet of seedlings emerging from dark potting mix along the front edge of the herb window box.
photos.tags: thai basil, seedlings, overhead, soil, herb box

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Soil moisture has recovered well since the prior day's dryness, rising into the mid-40s and supporting visible improvement in seedling posture. Basil sprouts appear healthy, upright, and evenly green, with multiple seedlings showing the first true-leaf tips emerging. pH has rebounded naturally after the prior watering, now reading 5.21 and trending back toward a stable early-basil range. Despite a high midday soil temperature near the planter edge, no heat stress symptoms are present.
journal.actions: No immediate watering needed since moisture is currently adequate. Continue providing full sun exposure while monitoring moisture levels during the hotter parts of the afternoon.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture later today or tomorrow morning to ensure it remains above the low-30 range as seedlings continue root development. Avoid fertilizer or lime additions while early growth remains sensitive. Expect first true leaves to begin opening within the next 24–48 hours.

photos.caption: Thai Basil seedling zone with upright sprouts and emerging true-leaf tips under bright midday sun.
photos.tags: thai-basil, sprouts, seedlings, true-leaf-tips, herb-box, soil

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight.
journal.observations: Soil moisture has dropped significantly since the day before, leaving the basil seed zone dry and causing slight wilt in some cotyledons. pH has dipped back into the acidic range, likely reflecting a localized pocket of acidic mix and the dry conditions rather than a planter-wide trend. Seedlings remain viable and upright, and the cloudy conditions today should reduce heat stress as they recover from the morning dryness.
journal.actions: Apply gentle surface watering to rehydrate the upper soil layer without disturbing seedlings or washing lime deeper.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture later today to ensure it remains above the low-30 range as seedlings continue establishing roots. Avoid additional lime and allow pH to stabilize naturally with the renewed moisture. Continue providing bright conditions and monitor seedling posture as they rehydrate.
follow_up: [11:32 AM] Applied gentle watering along basil row to rehydrate the top layer without washing lime deeper.

photos.caption: Thai Basil seedling zone late morning with dry soil surface and visible sprouts.
photos.tags: thai-basil, sprouts, seedlings, soil, herb-box

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 60°F overnight.
journal.observations: pH has corrected into the optimal basil range after several days of lime activity, and moisture remains steady in the mid-50s. Sprouts in the Thai Basil section appear healthy, upright, and evenly green with early true-leaf nubs forming, consistent with the expected transition from germination into first-leaf development. Soil surface shows good texture without crusting or compaction, and no stress indicators such as wilting, discoloration, or damping-off are present.
journal.actions: No watering needed at this time since soil moisture is already appropriate for seedlings. Maintain full sun exposure and continue monitoring moisture and sprout posture through the late afternoon.
journal.next_steps: Check the top ¾ inch of soil in the evening or next morning; water gently only if the surface layer becomes dry. Watch for the first pair of true leaves to expand over the next 48–72 hours as temperatures remain favorable.

photos.caption: Thai Basil seedling zone with healthy upright sprouts and moist seedbed.
photos.tags: thai-basil, sprouts, seedlings, herb-box, soil

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: Midday reading shows Thai Basil seed zone warm and moderately moist with acidic pH. Sprouts are assumed present from prior day but not visually checked today due to missing photo; conditions are consistent with early seedling stage in strong sun.
journal.actions: No watering at midday since moisture is still adequate. Continue providing full sun exposure while monitoring for any wilting or surface crusting later in the day.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and sprout condition in the morning or evening when temperatures are cooler. If the top inch dries out or seedlings droop, plan a gentle surface watering around the basil row.

journal.conditions: Clear with full sun and a temperature of 70°F.
journal.observations: Early Thai Basil sprouts are present near the pole, appearing bright green and healthy. Soil moisture is moderate and pH remains acidic but improving from prior readings. No signs of damping-off, yellowing, or pest activity are visible.
journal.actions: No watering needed. Maintain full sun exposure.
journal.next_steps: Monitor sprout stability and soil moisture. Watch for continued pH improvement and plan gentle lime application if acidic conditions persist.
follow_up: [3:07 PM] Applied lime across herb box. Soil was very dry two knuckles down, so light surface watering was provided to re-moisten the upper layer without washing lime deeper.

photos.caption: Thai Basil sprout cluster.
photos.tags: thai-basil, sprouts

photos.caption: Herb box after lime application on the afternoon of 11/19.
photos.tags: herb-box, lime, follow-up

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 82°F dropping to 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: Soil is evenly moist after previous watering. No visible Thai Basil sprouts yet; seed zone remains intact and undisturbed.
journal.actions: No watering needed. Tray is left undisturbed to allow seeds to continue germination process.
journal.next_steps: Monitor for first basil sprout emergence over the next several days. Continue providing full sun and maintaining even moisture.

photos.caption: Thai Basil section with moist soil but no visible sprouts.
photos.tags: thai-basil, herb-box, soil

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: No visible Thai Basil sprouts yet. Soil is evenly moist after recent rehydration but pH remains on the acidic side, potentially slowing germination slightly.
journal.actions: Apply a light top-dress of lime to help raise pH. Maintain gentle surface moisture without over-watering.
journal.next_steps: Recheck pH and moisture in 24–48 hours. Watch for first basil sprout emergence later in the week as conditions improve.

photos.caption: Full herb planter view before basil has sprouted.
photos.tags: thai-basil, herb-box, overview

journal.conditions: Clear with morning shade transitioning to sun and a temperature of 67°F.
journal.observations: Soil is still on the dry side but improving compared to the previous day. No sprouts visible in this section yet as seeds continue early water uptake.
journal.actions: Applied gentle watering to keep the top layer evenly moist. No fertilizer needed at this stage.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture the next morning and continue watching for first signs of germination over the coming days.

photos.caption: Herb planter surface showing moistening soil and no sprouts yet.
photos.tags: herb-box, soil, pre-germination

journal.conditions: Clear with full sun and a temperature of 65°F.
journal.observations: Initial reading shows very dry soil and alkaline pH across the planter. No seedlings present; seeds are likely just beginning water uptake after sowing.
journal.actions: Applied thorough soaking to correct dryness, taking care not to displace seeds. No fertilizer at this stage.
journal.next_steps: Expect slow pH change over the coming days. Recheck moisture and pH with follow-up readings as germination begins.

photos.caption: First-day view of the herb planter with dry soil before rehydration.
photos.tags: herb-box, dry-soil, day-1
